text: When I saw this <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/juliasim-simulating-reality-upcoming-product-by-julia-computing/58785> I thought the announcement is 6 days late. :see_no_evil:

attachments.title: JuliaSim - Simulating Reality (upcoming product by Julia Computing)
attachments.text: JuliaSim: Simulating Reality Coming soon: JuliaSim is a next generation cloud-based simulation platform, combining the latest techniques in SciML with equation-based digital twin modeling and simulation. Surrogatize your models, use pre-accelerated models from the thousands of available models, generate digital twins from data, and more. Bringing Julia to Industrial Scale Modeling and Simulation JuliaSim allows you to directly import models from its Model Store into your Julia environment, ma...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: JuliaSim - Simulating Reality (upcoming product by Julia Computing)

elements.text: When I saw this
I thought the announcement is 6 days late.

text: I'm glad to see Julia doing this. That digital twin thing is becoming pretty trendy. I'm not convinced it isn't just a rebrand of stuff other people have been doing for years, but that's beside the point I guess. It's good to see such a young toolset keeping pace and in some ways doing better than something that's been around since the dawn of time (MatLab)

text: Simulated Reality in Julia? Maybe that is our existence! :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

text: yeah that's a lot of buzzwords, you have to be careful about doing that, it can kill off your credibility pretty quickly... OTOH if it gets them money, why not

elements.text: yeah that's a lot of buzzwords, you have to be careful about doing that, it can kill off your credibility pretty quickly... OTOH if it gets them money, why not

text: Yes, when we do a full announcement of it this summer though, you'll see that we hit all of the buzzwords. So it's not buzzwords for their own sake, like how DifferentialEquations.jl lists off every type of differential equation not to be fancy but as a feature list.

elements.text: Yes, when we do a full announcement of it this summer though, you'll see that we hit all of the buzzwords. So it's not buzzwords for their own sake, like how DifferentialEquations.jl lists off every type of differential equation not to be fancy but as a feature list.

text: This is more targeting the industry users though, the people who want pre-made models in certain domains, who want GUIs, etc.

elements.text: This is more targeting the industry users though, the people who want pre-made models in certain domains, who want GUIs, etc.

text: Yea it's a great idea, and there's nothing wrong with selling stuff that is known to be effective. In a lot of cases this is the "right thing to do", because CTO's, Directors, CEO's etc, would never care about or hire for someone to do modelling. They'd call it "risk" or mention some acronym they learned about wasteful projects. But if you call it a "Digital Twin" or "Industry 4.0" slap a GUI on it - all of a sudden they are doing sane things. Some places literally need to have something be a "product" before they'd ever pursue it, no matter how badly they need it.

elements.text: Yea it's a great idea, and there's nothing wrong with selling stuff that is known to be effective. In a lot of cases this is the "right thing to do", because CTO's, Directors, CEO's etc, would never care about or hire for someone to do modelling. They'd call it "risk" or mention some acronym they learned about wasteful projects. But if you call it a "Digital Twin" or "Industry 4.0" slap a GUI on it - all of a sudden they are doing sane things. Some places literally need to have something be a "product" before they'd ever pursue it, no matter how badly they need it.

text: I learned that with pharma. Pumas was going to be open source, but then no one would use it without funding a few million for FDA approval and GUIs and ... :shrug: Some things just need to be a product. A full curated model library with pre-accelerated surrogates of models is one. The academic and open source communities will be able to benefit from this as well, with of course SymbolicUtils.jl, Symbolics.jl, and ModelingToolkit.jl being some of the open source pieces that have come out of this project. The focus of the product is mostly towards the companies that want 1000 pre-made heart models and HVAC models etc. because they'd rather pay money than make the model themselves, but there will be nice pieces for academic engineers who are interested in Modelica or Simulink types of things.

The focus of the product is mostly towards the companies that want 1000 pre-made heart models and HVAC models etc. because they'd rather pay money than make the model themselves, but there will be nice pieces for academic engineers who are interested in Modelica or Simulink types of things.

text: Yea exactly, a lot of outsiders wouldn't understand it because it sounds like madness, because it kind of is madness, but it's the way it is.

text: I didn’t know what is a digital twin before I googled it due to this announcement. Is there a fundamental difference to ordinary models of.. hmm.. stuff.

text: There are data driven components mixed with the physical models and it learns to be a better model as more data is added to the system.

elements.text: There are data driven components mixed with the physical models and it learns to be a better model as more data is added to the system.

text: SpaceX maybe does something like that with the Starship.

text: Basically lots of places do this sort of thing and have been doing it for a while. Its a useful idea if you can break a system down. But MatLab and I think some other toolset started calling it a "digital twin" and the idea has since taken off in industry.
